citation.article-title: Methyloferula stellata gen. nov., sp. nov., an acidophilic, obligately methanotrophic bacterium that possesses only a soluble methane monooxygenase
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Methyloferula [Me.thy′lo.fe′ru.la. N.L. n. methylum the methyl group (from French methyle, back-formation from French methylune, coined from Gr. n. methu wine and Gr. n. hulê wood); N.L. pref. methyl- pertaining to the methyl radical; L. fem. n. ferula a rod; N.L. fem. n. Methyloferula methyl-using rod].
Gram-negative, aerobic, colourless, non-motile rods that occur singly or are arranged in rosettes and misshapen cell clusters.
Colonies are small, circular and smooth.
The colony colour varies from white to cream.
Prefer dilute media of low salt content.
Obligate utilizers of methane and methanol; the latter is the preferred growth substrate.
The G+C content of the DNA is 55.6–57.5 mol%.
Member of the class Alphaproteobacteria, family Beijerinckiaceae.
The type and only species is Methyloferula stellata.
Known habitats are acidic peatlands and soils.
